channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: What’s the sign for ‘centrifuge’? How we added scientific terms to Indian Sign Language
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00572-0

Molecular biologist Alka Rao brought together her research group and sign-language specialists to broaden access to science for deaf students in India.
item.dc:title: What’s the sign for ‘centrifuge’? How we added scientific terms to Indian Sign Language
item.dc:creator: Deepa Padamanaban

item.title: How our love of pets grew from a clash of world views
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00541-7

Indigenous Americans’ relationships with and knowledge of animals have influenced how Europeans have thought about animals since 1492.
item.dc:title: How our love of pets grew from a clash of world views
item.dc:creator: Surekha Davies

item.title: First private Moon lander touches down on lunar surface to make history
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00549-z

After a nailbiting descent, the Odysseus spacecraft lands near the lunar south pole and prepares to kick off a week of data-gathering.
item.dc:title: First private Moon lander touches down on lunar surface to make history
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Save lives in the next pandemic: ensure vaccine equity now
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00545-3

The proposed Pandemic Agreement must ensure that COVID-19 vaccine nationalism is never repeated; 290 scientists call for action.
item.dc:title: Save lives in the next pandemic: ensure vaccine equity now
item.dc:creator: Colin Carlson
Daniel Becker
Christian Happi
Zoe O’Donoghue
Tulio de Oliveira
Samuel O. Oyola
Timothée Poisot
Stephanie Seifert
Alexandra Phelan

item.title: Laser pulses engrave an unlikely surface: soap films
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00513-x

Bumping up the detergent content allows a laser pulse to carve a groove in ethereal films.
item.dc:title: Laser pulses engrave an unlikely surface: soap films

item.title: How whales sing without drowning, an anatomical mystery solved
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00561-3

Baleen whales sing using a modified larynx, but this leaves them them unable to escape human noise.
item.dc:title: How whales sing without drowning, an anatomical mystery solved

item.title: How egg cells handle their cellular rubbish
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00498-7

The discovery of a molecular recycling system in mouse oocytes might help scientists to understand why fertility declines with age.
item.dc:title: How egg cells handle their cellular rubbish

item.title: Arno A. Penzias (1933–2024), co-discoverer of the cosmic microwave background
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00555-1

Astrophysicist whose radio-wave observations confirmed the Big Bang origin of the Universe.
item.dc:title: Arno A. Penzias (1933–2024), co-discoverer of the cosmic microwave background
item.dc:creator: John Bally

item.title: CAR T therapy for multiple sclerosis enters US trials for first time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00470-5

Hopes are high that engineered immune cells, which are already in use to treat blood cancer, will halt the progression of a degenerative autoimmune disorder.
item.dc:title: CAR T therapy for multiple sclerosis enters US trials for first time
item.dc:creator: Asher Mullard

item.title: Supernova mystery solved: JWST reveals the fate of an iconic stellar explosion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00528-4

Decades-long quest ends as the landmark observatory detects signs of the 1987 blast’s central neutron star.
item.dc:title: Supernova mystery solved: JWST reveals the fate of an iconic stellar explosion
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Editorial Expression of Concern: Class 3 semaphorins control vascular morphogenesis by inhibiting integrin function
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07195-5

Editorial Expression of Concern: Class 3 semaphorins control vascular morphogenesis by inhibiting integrin function
item.dc:title: Editorial Expression of Concern: Class 3 semaphorins control vascular morphogenesis by inhibiting integrin function
item.dc:creator: Guido Serini

item.title: Double-side 2-dimensional/3-dimensional heterojunctions for inverted perovskite solar cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07189-3

Double-side 2-dimensional/3-dimensional heterojunctions for inverted perovskite solar cells
item.dc:title: Double-side 2-dimensional/3-dimensional heterojunctions for inverted perovskite solar cells

item.title: Author Correction: Senolytic CAR T cells reverse senescence-associated pathologies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07197-3

Author Correction: Senolytic CAR T cells reverse senescence-associated pathologies
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Senolytic CAR T cells reverse senescence-associated pathologies
item.dc:creator: Corina Amor

item.title: Why are we nice? Altruism’s origins are put to the test
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00539-1

Research suggests a combination of behaviours underlie the evolution of human cooperation, and researchers make an optical disc with enormous storage capacity.
item.dc:title: Why are we nice? Altruism’s origins are put to the test
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Buried microplastics complicate efforts to define the Anthropocene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00535-5

Plastic particles in sediments could help to pin down the start of a new geological epoch. But their ability to migrate to older layers is muddying the waters.
item.dc:title: Buried microplastics complicate efforts to define the Anthropocene
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Progressive unanchoring of Antarctic ice shelves since 1973
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07049-0

Pinning-point changes over three epochs spanning the periods 1973–1989, 1989–2000 and 2000−2022 were measured, and by proxy the changes to ice-shelf thickness back to 1973–1989 were inferred.
item.dc:title: Progressive unanchoring of Antarctic ice shelves since 1973
item.dc:creator: Bertie W. J. Miles
Robert G. Bingham

item.title: Super-additive cooperation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07077-w

Models show that human cooperation cannot evolve reliably under repeated interactions or under intergroup competitions, but combining the two mechanisms predicts a distinctive strategy, observed experimentally in Papua New Guinea, in which individuals exhibit cooperative reciprocity with ingroup partners and uncooperative reciprocity with outgroup partners.
item.dc:title: Super-additive cooperation
item.dc:creator: Charles Efferson
Helen Bernhard
Urs Fischbacher
Ernst Fehr

item.title: Targeted protein degradation via intramolecular bivalent glues
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07089-6

Studies using genetic screening, biophysical characterization and structural reconstitution elucidate the mechanism of action and enable rational design of a new class of functional compounds that glue target proteins to E3 ligases via intramolecularly bridging two domains to enhance intrinsic protein–protein interactions and promote target ubiquitination and degradation.
item.dc:title: Targeted protein degradation via intramolecular bivalent glues
item.dc:creator: Oliver Hsia
Matthias Hinterndorfer

item.title: Fractional quantum anomalous Hall effect in multilayer graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07010-7

Integer and fractional quantum anomalous Hall effects in a rhombohedral pentalayer graphene–hBN moiré superlattice are observed, providing an ideal platform for exploring charge fractionalization and (non-Abelian) anyonic braiding at zero magnetic field.
item.dc:title: Fractional quantum anomalous Hall effect in multilayer graphene
item.dc:creator: Zhengguang Lu
Tonghang Han
Yuxuan Yao
Aidan P. Reddy
Jixiang Yang
Junseok Seo

Liang Fu
Long Ju

item.title: Mechanisms of action and resistance in histone methylation-targeted therapy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07103-x

The mechanisms of action and resistance of valemetostat, an EZH1–EZH2 dual inhibitor, in patients with adult T cell leukaemia/lymphoma who initially responded but later showed disease progression are explored.
item.dc:title: Mechanisms of action and resistance in histone methylation-targeted therapy
item.dc:creator: Makoto Yamagishi

item.title: Monolithic silicon for high spatiotemporal translational photostimulation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07016-9

A silicon-based electrode system is described that allows tunable spatiotemporal photostimulation of cardiac systems, with the optoelectronic capabilities of these devices being demonstrated in mouse, rat and pig heart models.
item.dc:title: Monolithic silicon for high spatiotemporal translational photostimulation
item.dc:creator: Pengju Li
Jing Zhang

item.title: UFM1 E3 ligase promotes recycling of 60S ribosomal subunits from the ER
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07073-0

Structural and biochemical analyses reveal details of how UFM1 conjugation and deconjugation mediate ribosome recycling and quality control.
item.dc:title: UFM1 E3 ligase promotes recycling of 60S ribosomal subunits from the ER
item.dc:creator: Paul A. DaRosa

item.title: Evolutionary novelties underlie sound production in baleen whales
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07080-1

Studies of vocal production in baleen whales show that their larynx has evolved unique structures that enable their low-frequency vocalizations but limit their active communication range.
item.dc:title: Evolutionary novelties underlie sound production in baleen whales
item.dc:creator: Coen P. H. Elemans
Weili Jiang
Mikkel H. Jensen
Helena Pichler
Bo R. Mussman
Jacob Nattestad
Magnus Wahlberg
Xudong Zheng
Qian Xue
W. Tecumseh Fitch

item.title: Natural killer cell therapies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06945-1

This Review explores in detail the complexity of NK cell biology in humans and highlights the role of these cells in cancer immunity.
item.dc:title: Natural killer cell therapies
item.dc:creator: Eric Vivier
Lucas Rebuffet
Emilie Narni-Mancinelli
Stéphanie Cornen
Rob Y. Igarashi
Valeria R. Fantin

item.title: Activation of Thoeris antiviral system via SIR2 effector filament assembly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07092-x

A study reports that the Theoris anti-phage defence system is activated through helical filament assembly of the ThsA effector and details the activation mechanism.
item.dc:title: Activation of Thoeris antiviral system via SIR2 effector filament assembly
item.dc:creator: Giedre Tamulaitiene
Dziugas Sabonis
Giedrius Sasnauskas

Virginijus Siksnys

item.title: A 3D nanoscale optical disk memory with petabit capacity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06980-y

Optical nanoscale disk memory with petabit-level capacity is developed by extending the recording architecture to three dimensions with hundreds of layers, and exabit-level storage can be achieved by stacking the disks into arrays.
item.dc:title: A 3D nanoscale optical disk memory with petabit capacity
item.dc:creator: Miao Zhao
Jing Wen
Qiao Hu
Xunbin Wei
Yu-Wu Zhong
Hao Ruan
Min Gu

item.title: Prevalence of persistent SARS-CoV-2 in a large community surveillance study
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07029-4

Using viral sequence data, individuals with persistent SARS-CoV-2 infections were identified, and had higher odds of self-reporting long COVID, in a large community surveillance study.
item.dc:title: Prevalence of persistent SARS-CoV-2 in a large community surveillance study
item.dc:creator: Mahan Ghafari

item.title: Room temperature operation of germanium–silicon single-photon avalanche diode
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07076-x

A germanium–silicon single-photon avalanche diode operated at room temperature shows a noise-equivalent power improvement over the previous Ge-based single-photon avalanche diodes by 2–3.5 orders of magnitude.
item.dc:title: Room temperature operation of germanium–silicon single-photon avalanche diode
item.dc:creator: Neil Na
Yen-Cheng Lu

item.title: Twisted-layer boron nitride ceramic with high deformability and strength
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07036-5

A bulk ceramic composed of interlocked boron nitride nanoplates with a laminated structure of twist-stacked nanoslices is created using hot-pressing and spark plasma sintering, which exhibits large elastic and plastic deformability and high strength at room temperature.
item.dc:title: Twisted-layer boron nitride ceramic with high deformability and strength

item.title: Synaptic wiring motifs in posterior parietal cortex support decision-making
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07088-7

Excitatory pyramidal neurons preferentially target inhibitory interneurons with the same selectivity and, in turn, inhibitory interneurons preferentially target pyramidal neurons with opposite selectivity, forming an opponent inhibition motif that supports decision-making.
item.dc:title: Synaptic wiring motifs in posterior parietal cortex support decision-making
item.dc:creator: Aaron T. Kuan

item.title: Avoiding fusion plasma tearing instability with deep reinforcement learning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07024-9

Artificial intelligence control is used to avoid the emergence of disruptive tearing instabilities in the magnetically confined fusion plasma in the DIII-D tokamak reactor.
item.dc:title: Avoiding fusion plasma tearing instability with deep reinforcement learning
item.dc:creator: Jaemin Seo
SangKyeun Kim

item.title: Making cities mental health friendly for adolescents and young adults
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07005-4

A study examining how cities can foster well-being and positive mental health in young residents synthesizes opinions from researchers, practitioners, advocates and young people, highlighting factors that policymakers and urban planners should consider.
item.dc:title: Making cities mental health friendly for adolescents and young adults
item.dc:creator: Pamela Y. Collins

item.title: WNT signalling control by KDM5C during development affects cognition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07067-y

The demethylase KDM5C, mutations in which often lead to intellectual disability, is identified as a crucial player in regulating the precise timing of neurodevelopment together with the WNT signalling pathway.
item.dc:title: WNT signalling control by KDM5C during development affects cognition
item.dc:creator: Violetta Karwacki-Neisius

item.title: A lanthanide-rich kilonova in the aftermath of a long gamma-ray burst
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06979-5

A modelling analysis shows that an unusually long gamma-ray burst gave rise to a lanthanide-rich kilonova following the merger of a neutron star–neutron star or of a neutron star–black hole.
item.dc:title: A lanthanide-rich kilonova in the aftermath of a long gamma-ray burst

item.title: The UFM1 E3 ligase recognizes and releases 60S ribosomes from ER translocons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07093-w

Attachment of the ubiquitin-like modifier UFM1 to 60S ribosomes has a critical function in the release and recycling of stalled or terminated ribosomes from the endoplasmic reticulum membrane.
item.dc:title: The UFM1 E3 ligase recognizes and releases 60S ribosomes from ER translocons
item.dc:creator: Linda Makhlouf

item.title: B cells orchestrate tolerance to the neuromyelitis optica autoantigen AQP4
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07079-8

The immune system is tolerized against the neuromyelitis optica autoantigen AQP4 by thymic B cells, which present their endogenous AQP4 to AQP4-reactive thymocytes.
item.dc:title: B cells orchestrate tolerance to the neuromyelitis optica autoantigen AQP4

item.title: IL-10 constrains sphingolipid metabolism to limit inflammation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07098-5

IL-10 exerts its anti-inflammatory activity in macrophages by increasing the expression of enzymes that promote fatty acid desaturation and downstream regulation of the transcription factor REL.
item.dc:title: IL-10 constrains sphingolipid metabolism to limit inflammation
item.dc:creator: Autumn G. York

item.title: Directive giant upconversion by supercritical bound states in the continuum
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06967-9

An experimental design consisting of a photonic-crystal nanoslab covered with upconversion nanoparticles demonstrates the phenomenon of supercritical coupling, resulting in giant enhancement of upconversion by photonic bound states in the continuum.
item.dc:title: Directive giant upconversion by supercritical bound states in the continuum

item.title: Claus Nielsen (1938–2024), zoologist of invertebrates
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00540-8

Danish marine biologist who proposed that the last common ancestor of flies and humans resembled a swimming larva.
item.dc:title: Claus Nielsen (1938–2024), zoologist of invertebrates
item.dc:creator: Max Telford
Andreas Hejnol
Detlev Arendt

item.title: Fractional quantum Hall effect at zero magnetic field observed in an unexpected material
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00067-y

The fractional quantum anomalous Hall effect occurs when the Hall resistance in a material is quantized to fractional multiples of the fundamental unit h/e2 at zero magnetic field. Observing the effect in a system consisting of a combination of five-layer graphene and hexagonal boron nitride enriches the family of topological matter phases, and opens up new opportunities in quantum computation.
item.dc:title: Fractional quantum Hall effect at zero magnetic field observed in an unexpected material

item.title: A human embryo model mimics early development and blood-cell formation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04129-5

Human embryos are extremely difficult to study. This lack of samples limits our understanding of crucial developmental stages, such as the early formation of blood cells. A stem-cell-based model closely captures the development of human embryonic and key extra-embryonic tissues after implantation, as well as the formation of early blood cells.
item.dc:title: A human embryo model mimics early development and blood-cell formation

item.title: Science can drive development and unity in Africa — as it does in the US and Europe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00510-0

A plan to establish Africa’s first continent-wide science fund should not be delayed any longer.
item.dc:title: Science can drive development and unity in Africa — as it does in the US and Europe

item.title: Why reciprocity is common in humans but rare in other animals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00308-0

Reciprocal cooperation can be advantageous, but why it is more common in humans than in other social animals is a puzzle. A modelling and experimental study pinpoints the conditions needed for reciprocity to evolve.
item.dc:title: Why reciprocity is common in humans but rare in other animals
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mathew

item.title: Backdoor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00336-w

The thrill of the chase.
item.dc:title: Backdoor
item.dc:creator: Gendel Gento

item.title: Light can restore a heart’s rhythm
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00303-5

Implantable electric pacemakers save millions of lives worldwide, but they aren’t perfect. A proof-of-concept study shows that using light to regulate a heartbeat might be a better option than existing strategies.
item.dc:title: Light can restore a heart’s rhythm
item.dc:creator: Igor R. Efimov

item.title: Drug-resistant microbes: ‘brain drain’ is derailing the fight to stop them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00534-6

A lack of investment is driving researchers who study antimicrobial resistance out of the field, an industry body warns.
item.dc:title: Drug-resistant microbes: ‘brain drain’ is derailing the fight to stop them
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

item.title: Rare isotopes formed in prelude to γ-ray burst
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00310-6

The afterglow of a long burst of γ-rays suggests that the events leading to these explosions can be sizeable sources of some of the Universe’s rare isotopes — and that classifications of γ-ray bursts are too simplistic.
item.dc:title: Rare isotopes formed in prelude to γ-ray burst
item.dc:creator: Daniel Kasen

item.title: Scientists under arrest: the researchers taking action over climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00480-3

Fed up with a lack of political progress in solving the climate problem, some researchers are becoming activists to slow global warming.
item.dc:title: Scientists under arrest: the researchers taking action over climate change
item.dc:creator: Daniel Grossman

item.title: The life and gruesome death of a bog man revealed after 5,000 years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00537-3

Vittrup Man, who died in his thirties, was a Scandinavian wanderer who settled down between 3300 and 3100 bc.
item.dc:title: The life and gruesome death of a bog man revealed after 5,000 years
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Why citizen scientists are gathering DNA from hundreds of lakes — on the same day
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00520-y

Massive environmental DNA project will take a record-setting snapshot of biodiversity worldwide.
item.dc:title: Why citizen scientists are gathering DNA from hundreds of lakes — on the same day
item.dc:creator: Lydia Larsen

item.title: Daily briefing: Great ‘Stone Age’ wall discovered in Baltic Sea
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00551-5

A string of boulders almost a kilometre long, now covered by the ocean, could be Europe’s oldest human-made megastructure. Plus, the 200-year anniversary of the first dinosaur described by science.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Great ‘Stone Age’ wall discovered in Baltic Sea
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: MEGA-CRISPR tool gives a power boost to cancer-fighting cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00511-z

A system that edits RNA rather than DNA can give new life to exhausted CAR T cells.
item.dc:title: MEGA-CRISPR tool gives a power boost to cancer-fighting cells
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Nanotraps boost light intensity for future optical devices
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00311-5

A method for configuring light-trapping devices promises better optical nanodevices by amplifying light and enhancing the emission efficiency of luminescent nanomaterials — without the need for complex technology upgrades.
item.dc:title: Nanotraps boost light intensity for future optical devices
item.dc:creator: Kirill Koshelev

item.title: How to boost your research: take a sabbatical in policy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00479-w

Academic researchers have a unique opportunity to benefit society — and their research — by spending time in government.
item.dc:title: How to boost your research: take a sabbatical in policy
item.dc:creator: Jordan Dworkin

item.title: Reducing carbon dioxide efficiently to reuse and recycle it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04135-7

Electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide holds promise for converting CO2 into valuable products but is hampered by stability issues and wasted carbon. A proton-exchange membrane that uses lead as a catalyst demonstrates the feasibility of durable and efficient CO2 reduction.
item.dc:title: Reducing carbon dioxide efficiently to reuse and recycle it

item.title: An innovative way for whales to sing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00307-1

Mammals make sounds when air flow causes paired tissue folds in their voice box to oscillate. However, such air flow in the baleen group of whales takes an unusual path, enabling them to make sounds in a previously unknown way.
item.dc:title: An innovative way for whales to sing
item.dc:creator: Joy S. Reidenberg

item.title: Judith Campisi (1948–2024), cell biologist who explored how cells age
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00538-2

Researcher who established the role of cellular senescence in cancer and ageing.
item.dc:title: Judith Campisi (1948–2024), cell biologist who explored how cells age
item.dc:creator: Jan Vijg
Jan Hoeijmakers

item.title: The Radcliffe Wave is Oscillating
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07127-3

The Radcliffe Wave is Oscillating
item.dc:title: The Radcliffe Wave is Oscillating
item.dc:creator: Ralf Konietzka
Alyssa A. Goodman
Catherine Zucker
Andreas Burkert
João Alves
Michael Foley
Cameren Swiggum
Maria Koller
Núria Miret-Roig

item.title: Just a few counselling sessions can hold postpartum depression at bay
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00512-y

Even talking to a non-specialist during pregnancy was enough to reduce the risk of depression and anxiety after birth.
item.dc:title: Just a few counselling sessions can hold postpartum depression at bay

item.title: Stockholm declaration on AI ethics: why others should sign
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00517-7

Stockholm declaration on AI ethics: why others should sign
item.dc:title: Stockholm declaration on AI ethics: why others should sign
item.dc:creator: Ross D. King
Teresa Scassa
Stefan Kramer
Hiroaki Kitano

item.title: From the archive: Tutankhamun’s coffin, and Darwin shares a letter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00428-7

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: Tutankhamun’s coffin, and Darwin shares a letter

item.title: New Chinese databases are a boost for rare-disease science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00515-9

New Chinese databases are a boost for rare-disease science
item.dc:title: New Chinese databases are a boost for rare-disease science
item.dc:creator: Jishizhan Chen

item.title: Triple win: solar farms in deserts can boost power, incomes and ecosystems
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00516-8

Triple win: solar farms in deserts can boost power, incomes and ecosystems
item.dc:title: Triple win: solar farms in deserts can boost power, incomes and ecosystems
item.dc:creator: Haimeng Liu
Jianguo Liu

item.title: Pay rises for Serbia’s top 10% of research scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00514-w

Pay rises for Serbia’s top 10% of research scientists
item.dc:title: Pay rises for Serbia’s top 10% of research scientists
item.dc:creator: Dejan Brkić

item.title: Ancient bronze hand’s inscription points to origins of Basque language
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00507-9

Text on an artefact found in northern Spain resembles a present-day Basque word that means ‘of good fortune’.
item.dc:title: Ancient bronze hand’s inscription points to origins of Basque language

item.title: Daily briefing: The decimal point is 150 years older than we thought
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00531-9

Oldest known decimal point discover by historian while teaching at maths camp. Plus, survey of human diversity yields millions of undiscovered genetic variants and how mind-reading devices are revealing the brain’s secrets.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: The decimal point is 150 years older than we thought
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: 200 years of naming dinosaurs: scientists call for overhaul of antiquated system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00388-y

Some palaeontologists want more rigorous guidelines for naming species, along with action to address problematic historical practices.
item.dc:title: 200 years of naming dinosaurs: scientists call for overhaul of antiquated system
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Generative AI’s environmental costs are soaring — and mostly secret
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00478-x

First-of-its-kind US bill would address the environmental costs of the technology, but there’s a long way to go.
item.dc:title: Generative AI’s environmental costs are soaring — and mostly secret
item.dc:creator: Kate Crawford

item.title: R&D budget cut could be the final straw for South Korea’s young scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00525-7

As early-career researchers, we fear that our peers will struggle to stay afloat amid sudden and confusing budget constraints.
item.dc:title: R&D budget cut could be the final straw for South Korea’s young scientists
item.dc:creator: Bongjae Kim
Ara Go

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: Google AI will help to map methane pollution from space
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00532-8

Data from a soon-to-be-launched satellite will help to create the most comprehensive global methane map. Plus, OpenAI’s video generator Sora could open the deepfake floodgates and what the EU’s tough AI law means for research and ChatGPT.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: Google AI will help to map methane pollution from space
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: It’s time for countries to honour their million-dollar biodiversity pledges
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00509-7

Promises to safeguard biodiversity need to be translated into money in the bank.
item.dc:title: It’s time for countries to honour their million-dollar biodiversity pledges

item.title: Mind-reading devices are revealing the brain’s secrets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00481-2

Implants and other technologies that decode neural activity can restore people’s abilities to move and speak — and help researchers to understand how the brain works.
item.dc:title: Mind-reading devices are revealing the brain’s secrets
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Building precision instruments to explore the cosmos
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00484-z

Phil Korngut tests NASA’s SPHEREx telescope under extreme conditions at his laboratory in California.
item.dc:title: Building precision instruments to explore the cosmos
item.dc:creator: Rachael Pells

item.title: Genetic drivers of heterogeneity in type 2 diabetes pathophysiology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07019-6

A meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies of type 2 diabetes (T2D) identifies more than 600 T2D-associated loci; integrating physiological trait and single-cell chromatin accessibility data at these loci sheds light on heterogeneity within the T2D phenotype.
item.dc:title: Genetic drivers of heterogeneity in type 2 diabetes pathophysiology

item.title: Genomic data in the All of Us Research Program
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06957-x

A study describes the release of clinical-grade whole-genome sequence data for 245,388 diverse participants by the All of Us Research Program and characterizes the properties of the dataset.
item.dc:title: Genomic data in the All of Us Research Program
